results.title: Royal visit to Melbourne 1963 [Work print]
results.creator_credit: H. Rodney Power, David Swift and State Film Centre of Victoria
results.brief_description: Work print footage of the royal visit in 1963. Includes aerial views of Melbourne, the arrival of the royal yacht, The Queen and Price Phillip being greeted by dignitaries, the inspection of troops, passing crowds in a Rolls Royce, the arrival at a racetrack and a reception at the Melbourne Town Hall
results.creator_credit_for_label: H. Rodney Power, David Swift and State Film Centre of Victoria

results.title: Royal visit to Melbourne 1963
results.creator_credit: H. Rodney Power, David Swift and State Film Centre of Victoria
results.brief_description: Colour film record of the visit to Melbourne of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II and His Royal Highness the Duke of Edinburgh. The three crowded, exciting days are show in detail. Includes the arrival of Her Majesty, presentation of the cup at the races at Flemington, a glittering State reception, service at Scot’s Church, Myer Music Bowl concert, Moomba parade, waving to country children en route to open the Royal Children’s Hospital, investiture at Government House, and farewell at the wharf.
results.creator_credit_for_label: H. Rodney Power, David Swift and State Film Centre of Victoria

results.title: [Len Moncur Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
This films shows the 1956 Melbourne Olympic Games, including the opening ceremony, athletes competing in events, decorations in the city and the arrival of Prince Philip to close the Olympic Games.

Selected highlights list:
00:03:51:00 Olympic sign featuring torch, ‘1956’ and the rings
00:08:27:00 cyclists on a velodrome
00:09:57:00 some spectacular diving at the Olympic Swimming Stadium
00:11:44:00 torch bearers running with the Olympic torch
00:13:45:00 the Opening Ceremony
00:20:10:00 Ron Clarke running into the stadium
00:21:00:00 Clarke lighting the cauldron
00:25:35:00 television broadcast vans including the Herald Sun, the ABC and GTV9
00:25:49:00 various track and field events
00:33:30:00 athletes walking up through the crowd of spectators
00:35:41:00 newspaper headlines for Betty Cuthbert’s win
00:41:47:00 Flinders Street Station decorated with the Olympic rings and flags
00:49:00:00 licence plate with Olympic rings
00:49:48:00 on the harbour for yachting
00:51:50:00 the arrival of Prince Philip
00:54:30:00 crowds, including people in costume
00:54:50:00 rows of parked 1950s cars
01:00:52:00 athletes sign autographs
01:02:01:00 a fallen cyclist is helped up by two officials
01:04:07:00 country flags lining a boulevard
01:11:12:00 a brass band
01:16:00:00 Olympic rings lit up at night
01:16:35:00 the closing ceremony

results.title: [Orsola: Teramo, 1960]
results.brief_description:
In the course of a day, Orsola writes her fiancé, Ulderico Ciabarra, a letter, goes out to post it and reads a magazine in the sunshine. The filmmaker, Francesco Di Silvano, was a family acquaintance and cinema enthusiast who proposed the film as a gift Orsola could send her fiancé, recently settled in Melbourne, Australia. The children that appear in the final sequence are related to the filmmaker.

Note: An excerpt from ‘Orsola: Teramo, 1960’ appears in ‘Innamorati’ (2001/3); a four minute digital storytelling work created by Roberta Ciabarra, ACMI Film Programer and daughter of Orsola and Ulderico, as part of a pilot workshop conducted at ACMI in 2001.For technical reasons a re-record of the narration was done in 2003.

Donor has requested that any de-accessioning of the 8mm film that it be returned to him or the family. File Note with Governance.
results.description:
A ‘day in the life’ of a young woman whose fiancé has emigrated to Melbourne, Australia. In the course of a day, Orsola writes her fiancé, Ulderico, a letter, goes out to post it and reads a magazine in the sunshine.

The filmmaker, Francesco Di Silvano, was a family acquaintance and cinema enthusiast who proposed the film as a gift Orsola could send her fiancé, recently settled in Melbourne, Australia.

The related work “Innamorati” - made by Orsola’s daughter - tells the moving story of Orsola’s marriage and her journey to Australia to be reunited with her husband.
description_for_label:
In the course of a day, Orsola writes her fiancé, Ulderico Ciabarra, a letter, goes out to post it and reads a magazine in the sunshine. The filmmaker, Francesco Di Silvano, was a family acquaintance and cinema enthusiast who proposed the film as a gift Orsola could send her fiancé, recently settled in Melbourne, Australia. The children that appear in the final sequence are related to the filmmaker.

Note: An excerpt from ‘Orsola: Teramo, 1960’ appears in ‘Innamorati’ (2001/3); a four minute digital storytelling work created by Roberta Ciabarra, ACMI Film Programer and daughter of Orsola and Ulderico, as part of a pilot workshop conducted at ACMI in 2001.For technical reasons a re-record of the narration was done in 2003.

Donor has requested that any de-accessioning of the 8mm film that it be returned to him or the family. File Note with Governance.

results.title: You've changed
results.brief_description: From the time he was awarded a Churchill Fellowship in 1969, Conrad’s life has been one of achievement. A skilled builder, a respected intellect and an icon in forestry aviation, Conrad now needs full-time care due to dementia. Created as part of ‘Memory’s Voice: Capturing Stories of Courage’ in association with Vic Health and the Alzheimer’s Association.

group.title: Memory's voice: capturing stories of courage

results.title: Passionate pursuits
results.brief_description: This story was created for Robin Hodder’s grandchildren to celebrate his extraordinary achievements as an Olympic sportsman, a husband of 38 years and the world’s greatest dad. Created as part of the ‘Memory’s Voice: Capturing Stories of Courage’ workshop, an ACMI Digital Storytelling Project in association with Alzheimer’s Australia Vic and in partnership with VicHealth.

group.title: Memory's voice: capturing stories of courage

results.title: Max and Noel Oliver's story
results.brief_description:
Alzheimer’s sufferer Max together with his wife Noel have told a story for their granddaughters that celebrates their life together as well as capturing Max’s memories of his son, the children’s father, who died when they were very young. Created as part of the ‘Memory’s Voice: Capturing Stories of Courage’ workshop, an ACMI Digital Storytelling Project in association with Alzheimer’s Australia Vic and in partnership with VicHealth.
You can create your own Digital Story. Ask at the Information Desk or visit www.acmi.net.au/digitalstorytelling

group.title: Memory's voice: capturing stories of courage

results.title: Shearing at Big Billabong
results.brief_description: Intended primarily for screening to English school children, this film shows all the processes employed at a shearing shed, from mustering the sheep to the transportation of the bales of wool to the railhead. This film was produced on a big sheep station in New South Wales.
results.description: Intended primarily for screening to English school children, this film shows all the processes employed at a shearing shed, from mustering the sheep to the transportation of the bales of wool to the railhead. This film was produced on a big sheep station in New South Wales.

results.title: [Raymond Penington Home Movies: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
The Raymond Penington Home Movie Collection is a collection of 16mm colour and black-and-white films made between 1938 and 1965. Dr. Raymond Penington (born 1903) was a medical doctor from Melbourne, Victoria. He and his wife Edith lived in Papua New Guinea in the late 1920s before returning to Melbourne in 1931 and settling in Canterbury. They had three children, Margaret, Vivienne and Jocelyn. His home movies focus on family life in Melbourne and holidays in regional Victoria.

The first half of this film is long scenes of the sea interchanged with a koala in a tree.

Later we see Edith Penington holding the koala which appears to be domesticated.

Much of the rest of the film is following this koala as it eats and climbs trees.

There is also a brief moment with a penguin and some sheep.

The film finishes with Edith Penington fishing.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:25:00 koala in a tree
00:02:17:00 Dr Penington climbing a tree to pat the koala
00:04:13:00 Edith Penington cuddling a koala bear as it is fed
00:04:35:00 the koala bear climbs into the trees
00:04:55:00 Dr Penington cuddling the koala bear and feeding it
00:06:20:00 penguin being released running to its burrow
00:06:23:00 Dr Penington climbs into a tree with the koala
00:06:38:00 Edith Penington fishing

results.title: [Kodak Cinegraph compilation. No. 06]
results.brief_description: A compilation of silent newsreels including: 1. Wonderful Lake Taupo and trout fishing. 2. North Island - Rotorua, geyserland, a volcano and skiing. Boating on the Wanganui River. 3. Perth, WA - Re-enactment of Fremantle and Stirling proclaiming Western Australian colony in 1829. Winter surfing at Cottesloe and country scenes. 4. The Empire Games in Sydney 1938 - track and field, swimming and diving, and rowing on the Nepean River.
